nodes.text: The widespread use of constant elasticity of substitution (CES) functions in integrated assessment models (IAMs) misrepresents long-term technology transitions and produces artifacts such as monotonically and exponentially increasing carbon prices that are not representative of technical substitutability or realistic costs
CES functions are share-preserving and were developed for capital-labor substitution where inputs are neither fully dominant nor fully substitutable

Mathematically, CES implies a marginal rate of technical substitution that depends on the ratio of factor shares so replacing a large incumbent share requires exponentially increasing amounts of the substitute as substitution proceeds

Applying CES to fossil (F) and renewable (R) energy inputs yields model behavior where increasing R to replace F requires exponentially growing R quantities and implies exponentially rising relative fossil prices and carbon taxes

A stylized CES example in the paper using CES equations and Lagrangian optimization shows that with an initial global fossil share of about 85% reducing it to ~55% may require a 13-fold increase in renewable input for sigma=1.5 and leads to carbon taxes many orders of magnitude above base fossil cost
When energy demand grows (non-constant output), the CES-driven exponential requirements on substitute quantities and carbon prices are further exaggerated
Historical technological and energy transitions display S-curve (logistic, Gompertz, Bass) dynamics with dynamically evolving elasticity of substitution and decreasing costs as deployment proceeds

Because CES cannot represent an evolving elasticity it cannot reproduce empirically observed S-curve transitions and therefore is inappropriate for long-term physio-technical energy transition modeling

Major IAMs and hybrid models (examples: GTEM-C, MIT EPPA, GCAM, MERGE, others surveyed) employ CES variants or nested CES structures for production and energy modules leading to similarly shaped outcomes of exponentially rising carbon prices and limited renewable penetration in their scenarios

The CES-induced artifacts in IAM outputs create three policy-level problems: price diversion (overreliance on carbon price signals over physical planning), sticker shock (perceived prohibitive mitigation costs), and technological myopia (models favor incumbent-included technologies like CCS, nuclear, biomass because CES preserves initial shares)

A methodological modification using dynamically varying elasticity of substitution (e.g., linearly or exponentially decreasing rho) can reproduce S-curve-like substitution patterns and produce more realistic, non-exponentially rising carbon price trajectories within existing model structures

Simulations with dynamic elasticity (presented in the paper) demonstrate that allowing elasticity to evolve yields substitution and carbon price dynamics consistent with historical diffusion and technical learning, reducing the extreme carbon price peaks produced by static CES

Given empirical evidence of declining costs and deployment-driven learning for renewables, any realistic carbon price should be bounded by substitute technology costs and decline as substitutes scale, contradicting IAMs' CES-driven exponential carbon price projections

The authors recommend either (a) modifying IAMs to incorporate dynamic elasticities calibrated to technical diffusion and physical constraints or (b) adopting fundamentally physical energy-system models that directly represent energy flows, storage, and deployment targets rather than relying solely on price-based economic substitution

Limitation and assumption: CES was originally intended for short-run capital-labor substitution and IAMs additionally suffer from external assumptions issues (sensitivity to discount rate, arbitrary climate damage functions, and poor treatment of catastrophic tails) which are separate but compounding problems
